term_definitions.items: Transplant in Follow-up (register encounter with the patient)
Transplant not in follow-up due to graft failure
Days between transplant and event status

This fields relates to the follow-up event status, it describes the duration between the follow-up status. So it should hold for the following cases:
- In follow-up: days between transplant and patient encounter this report is about - Lost to follow-up: days between transplant and date conclusion patient was lost to follow-up - Patient deceased: days between transplant and date of death - Graft failed: days between transplant and irreversable graft failure
The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
For example: 'Sodium', 'White cell count', 'T3'. Commonly coded with an external terminology,
The value of the analyte result.
Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range to this result or may carry text or coded textual guidance as to whether the result is within the normal range.
For example, 'within normal limits for age and sex'.
The status of the result value.
The date and/or time that the analyte result was issued for the recorded ‘Analyte result status’.
Further detail regarding an individual result.
The existence of the test is registered in the Laboratory Information System, but there is nothing yet available.
This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) Test Result: data in the Test Result may be incomplete or unverified.
Verified early results are available, but not all results are final. This is a sub-category of 'Partial'.
The Test result is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist, and result data has been changed.
Subsequent to being final, the report has been modified by adding new content. The existing content is unchanged. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release.
The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed (also sometimes called 'aborted').
Actual value of the analyte result. The value of this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte.
e.g. 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Normally coded terminologies will be used for example, LOINC, NPU or SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.
The date and/or time that the analyte result was medically validated.
Identifier for the specimen used for the analyte result.
The intended position of this analyte result within the overall sequence of analyte results.
For example: ''1' '2', '3'. Where multiple analyte results are reported, the 'Analyte result sequence' makes the order in which they were reported explicit.
The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
For example: 'Sodium', 'White cell count', 'T3'. Commonly coded with an external terminology,
The value of the analyte result.
Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range to this result or may carry text or coded textual guidance as to whether the result is within the normal range.
For example, 'within normal limits for age and sex'.
The status of the result value.
The date and/or time that the analyte result was issued for the recorded ‘Analyte result status’.
Further detail regarding an individual result.
The existence of the test is registered in the Laboratory Information System, but there is nothing yet available.
This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) Test Result: data in the Test Result may be incomplete or unverified.
Verified early results are available, but not all results are final. This is a sub-category of 'Partial'.
The Test result is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist, and result data has been changed.
Subsequent to being final, the report has been modified by adding new content. The existing content is unchanged. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release.
The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed (also sometimes called 'aborted').
Actual value of the analyte result. The value of this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte.
e.g. 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Normally coded terminologies will be used for example, LOINC, NPU or SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.
The date and/or time that the analyte result was medically validated.
Identifier for the specimen used for the analyte result.
The intended position of this analyte result within the overall sequence of analyte results.
For example: ''1' '2', '3'. Where multiple analyte results are reported, the 'Analyte result sequence' makes the order in which they were reported explicit.
The findings and interpretation of a pathology laboratory test performed on patient-related specimens.

This archetype may be used to record a single valued test, but will often be specialised or templated to represent multiple value or 'panel' tests. This archetype also acts as the parent for specialisations appropriate for more specific laboratory tests, e.g. microbiology, histopathology.
Last sf12 score before follow-up moment.
Identification of the pathology test performed, sometimes including specimen type and patient state.

A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred, where possible. May be coded with LOINC or Snomed-CT. Examples include "Glucose", "Urea and Electrolytes", "Swab", “Cortisol (am)” or "Liver Biopsy".
Rich text or other multimedia representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service.
Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.
Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test.
Details of a clinician or organisation who will receive a copy of the laboratory test result.
This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) Test Result: data in the Test Result may be incomplete or unverified.
The Test result is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist, and result data has been changed.
Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the laboratory test results.
The local ID assigned to the test order by the order requester.
Equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.
The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).

Assigning an identifier to a request by the Laboratory lnformation System (LIS) enables tracking progress of the request and enables linking results to requests. It also provides a reference to assist with enquiries and it is usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

Details about the specimen if all individual test results are derived from the same specimen. If the specimen type is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test result name, then this additional data is not required. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per 'Result group'.
The local identifier given to the laboratory test result by the Laboratory Information System.
The status of the laboratory test result as a whole.
The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed (also sometimes called 'aborted').
The date and/or time that the entire result was issued for the recorded ‘Test Report Status’.
The diagnostic service that performs the examination.

For example, biochemistry, haematology. This helps clinicians filter for broad categories of results accoridng to local laboratory arrangements. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.
Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test result.
Details concerning a single laboratory test requested.
Usually there is one test request (or "order") for each result, however in some circumstances multiple test requests may be represented using a single Pathology test result archetype.
Details about the reported results, possibly an individual analyte, a group, panel or battery of multiple results, or a more complex and specific structure.
Single word, phrase or brief description representing the narrative in the 'Conclusion'.
Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results, which may include a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.
In HL7 fhir this information is held within the linked requestDetail.clinical Notes.
Additional narrative about the test not captured in other fields.
Identification of the original laboratory test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.
The existence of the test is registered in the Laboratory Information System, but there is nothing yet available.
Additional structured details of laboratory test methodology followed. For example, structured details about the laboratory method and data interpretation used.
True if a point of care device supplies the test result rather than a formal laboratory service.
Aspects of the condition or circumstances of the patient that may alter interpretation of the laboratory test.
Details of patient state that may alter interpretation of the laboratory test.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist.
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release.
Slot to allow extension to support localisation or alignment with other standards/ reference models.
Center responsible for the transplant procedure
Center responible for the follow-up of he transplanted patient
Center that the transplant procedure took place at

Should be used to indicate the sequence of the transplant, specifically in cases when transplant date or transplant_ID cannot discriminate the order of the transplants. For instance transplant_ID is a random unique ID and Transplant date is only recorded as Year of transplant.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
